author: OtherSideNotes
text: A U.S. official has alleged wrongdoing by U.S. spy chief Tulsi Gabbard in a complaint that is so highly classified it has sparked months of wrangling over how to share it with Congress, according to people familiar with the matter.
aiSummary: A classified whistleblower complaint alleging misconduct by the director of national intelligence has been withheld from Congress for months over secrecy and privilege disputes, raising concerns that national security classification may be delaying or blocking oversight.

replies.author: üåº DeePlorable üë©‚Äçüíª
replies.text: TRANSLATION: Tulsi Gabbard is exposing actual vote fraud, and is close to exposing more, so us, and our friends are getting scared and need to do some misdirection.

replies.author: MikeJ
replies.text: More likely selling US intel to Russia.

replies.author: becca
replies.text: That sounds bad

replies.author: MisterChip
replies.text: Literally all of us at home already know what it is, she is a Russia asset.

replies.author: AlanN
replies.text: If it‚Äôs classified, Congress still needs a process for oversight. Otherwise classification becomes a shield.

replies.author: AaronK
replies.text: What‚Äôs the timeline here‚Äîwhen was the complaint filed vs when oversight committees were notified?

replies.author: uriüß°üíú
replies.text: If you‚Äôre really on the up and up, why has a whistleblower report that would typically go to Congress in 7-14 days been sitting in a safe for 8 months?

replies.author: Gayle
replies.text: Hard to judge without specifics. But the secrecy wrangling is the story in itself.

replies.author: ReadingRoom
replies.text: There should be a standard secure reading room protocol so these disputes don‚Äôt stall indefinitely.

replies.author: LDH
replies.text: Release the whistleblower report. Who are you working for?

replies.author: BillW
replies.text: Anyone have a reliable breakdown of what‚Äôs alleged (without speculation)?

replies.author: ThreadDigest
replies.text: The bigger issue is whether privilege claims can override lawful congressional review.

author: CityArtsWatch
text: Trump to close Kennedy Center for two years, amid falling ticket sales and a growing list of performer cancellations, sparking more controversy over DC venue
aiSummary: Trump plans to close the Kennedy Center for two years following artist boycotts and falling attendance after his takeover of its board and branding. Critics note the venue underwent a $250M renovation in 2019 and question whether ‚Äúdilapidation‚Äù claims mask governance and backlash issues.

replies.author: DanS
replies.text: Trump wants to own every building in America and have his name on every bulding in America

replies.author: OtherSideNotes
replies.text: Libs heads explode in...3...2...1

replies.author: howard
replies.text: Trump closes Kennedy Center amidst declining visitation due to his marking the edifice with his own name. Trump believes in this way he can cover up the public rejection of his shameful desecration of a once popular and honorable memorial to JFK.

replies.author: theaterkid88
replies.text: Two years is a long time to shut down a cultural venue. What‚Äôs the actual renovation plan?

replies.author: numbers_guy
replies.text: If sales are down, closing removes revenue entirely. Curious what the financial model is.

replies.author: stageleft
replies.text: Performers cancel when they don‚Äôt trust governance. Fix governance first.

replies.author: dc_local
replies.text: DC already struggles with arts funding‚Äîthis will ripple to staff and local gigs.

replies.author: reno_truth
replies.text: Wasn‚Äôt there a major renovation not that long ago? Confused about the 'dilapidated' claim.

replies.author: seat12
replies.text: Attendance trends matter, but boycotts are also a signal. Both can be true.

replies.author: policyish
replies.text: This story feels like politics colliding with an institution that needs stability.

replies.author: just_a_fan
replies.text: I just want great shows and predictable seasons. Leadership drama ruins programming.

replies.author: uniondad
replies.text: Staff and vendors will take the hit long before any politician does.

author: MetroPolicy
text: Trump signs $1.2T funding bill to end shutdown after the House passed spending bills to end the partial government shutdown and buy time for bipartisan talks on new ICE accountability measures.
aiSummary: Trump signed a $1.2 trillion funding package ending the brief partial shutdown after a narrow 217‚Äì215 House vote. Most agencies are funded through September, but DHS is funded for only two weeks, setting up a Feb. 13 deadline and a high-stakes fight over immigration enforcement. Democrats are demanding changes to ICE/CBP operations after federal agents fatally shot two U.S. citizens in Minneapolis in January.

replies.author: fedmom
replies.text: Finally. Shutdowns are a nightmare for workers and contractors. Stop doing this to people.

replies.author: MarkS
replies.text: So we‚Äôre right back here in two weeks for DHS. Kicking the can, but faster.

replies.author: cspanjunkie
replies.text: 217‚Äì215 is razor thin. That‚Äôs not a mandate; that‚Äôs barely functioning.

replies.author: gradschooler
replies.text: Funding most agencies to September but DHS to Feb 13 is basically a planned cliffhanger.

replies.author: borderhotake
replies.text: Why? This should have been done to shut ICE down . Can you imagine how much better this country would be if they would have given the their money to all the local police for personal and equipment?

replies.author: legaleagle-ish
replies.text: If agents killed two citizens, oversight and standards are legitimate to debate‚Äîregardless of immigration politics.

replies.author: warrants?
replies.text: The warrant idea is interesting: where‚Äôs the line between enforcement efficiency and civil liberties?

replies.author: mpls_local
replies.text: The January shootings should be fully investigated before anyone shrugs this off as ‚Äòpolitics‚Äô.

replies.author: hillwatcher
replies.text: GOP letting Trump negotiate is predictable, but it also means everything hinges on his priorities.

replies.author: communityvoice
replies.text: Calling DHS ‚Äòrogue‚Äô is strong language, but DHS shouldn‚Äôt be above accountability.

replies.author: shutdown_skeptic
replies.text: This whole process incentivizes brinkmanship. Two-week DHS funding proves it.

replies.author: hardliner
replies.text: Triple their budget, triple their deports. Only good solution.

author: PublicSquare
text: A federal judge ruled that 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos, detained by ICE alongside his father, should not remain in federal custody. Data and analysis suggest ICE is increasingly detaining young children amid President Trump‚Äôs mass deportation efforts.
aiSummary: A federal judge ordered the release of a five-year-old asylum-seeking child and his father, criticizing ICE tactics as quota-driven rather than humanitarian. The case has intensified scrutiny of child detention practices amid pending asylum claims.

replies.author: paige
replies.text: I hope his family sues for every penny they can get. Poor kid. I hope he isn‚Äôt totally scarred for life from this experience

replies.author: MikeH
replies.text: He belongs with his family, and his family belongs in their home country, NOT HERE.

replies.author: nyc_insider
replies.text: MAGA is furious kids are being released from jail

replies.author: emma_b
replies.text: Families should stay together no matter what

replies.author: dad_thoughts
replies.text: I contend that any trauma was caused by the parent(s.) The officers cared for, fed him and deescalated the situation. Can you imagine watching your cowardly father run away from you, leaving you with strangers?

replies.author: case_reader
replies.text: Does anyone have the actual ruling text or a reputable summary of the judge‚Äôs reasoning?

replies.author: just_saying
replies.text: A federal judge = Liberal Activist

replies.author: border_process
replies.text: Regardless of politics, clear standards and accountability would reduce abuse.

replies.author: socialworkgal
replies.text: Even short detention can be traumatic at that age. Support services matter.

replies.author: civicdad
replies.text: We need enforcement that doesn‚Äôt create irreversible harm to kids.

replies.author: process_matters
replies.text: If data show an increase, oversight should ask why!.

replies.author: localreporterish
replies.text: Stories like this get lost in the aggregate. The human impact is real.
